name: Navigation Bar (Responsive) with Mobile Menu
description: A responsive navigation bar component with mobile hamburger menu, sticky scroll behavior, optional transparent-to-solid transition, and first-class dropdown support. Supports marketing (logo + links + CTA) and app (user menu, notifications) variants.

framework.description: Identify the UI framework and routing primitives so the navbar matches existing conventions.
detectionSteps: Inspect package.json dependencies to identify the framework (React/Vue/Angular/Svelte) and router (Next.js, react-router, Vue Router, etc.).
Open 2-3 existing components to confirm patterns (hooks vs composition API, state conventions, folder structure).
Confirm SSR/hydration constraints (e.g., Next.js/Nuxt): do not access window/document before mount.

stylingSystem.description: Detect the project's styling approach and use ONLY that approach (no new styling systems).
detectionSteps: Inspect package.json for tailwindcss, sass, styled-components, @emotion/*, vanilla-extract, css-modules tooling.
Inspect existing components: Tailwind utility usage vs CSS Modules vs SCSS imports vs styled-components/emotion patterns.
Inspect config files (tailwind.config.*, postcss.config.*, vite/webpack configs) to confirm the styling pipeline.
adaptationRules: If Tailwind is present, use Tailwind utility classes and existing token conventions; do not add new CSS files.
If CSS Modules are used, create/extend a module stylesheet and follow existing naming conventions; avoid inline style attributes.
If SCSS is used, create/extend SCSS in the existing structure; keep mixins/variables consistent.
If styled-components/emotion is used, implement styles using that library; do not introduce class-based stylesheets.
If vanilla CSS is used, define reusable classes in a stylesheet (no inline style attributes).

designTokens.description: Align spacing, typography, color surfaces, and elevation to existing project tokens.
detectionSteps: Locate token sources (CSS variables, Tailwind theme, theme files, design system packages).
Identify surface/background colors and elevation/shadows for sticky/solid states.
Identify spacing/typography scales used in existing header/nav components.

must: Match existing framework component patterns and routing/link components.
Match existing styling conventions exactly (Tailwind/CSS Modules/SCSS/styled-components/etc.).
Implement mobile menu as a modal dialog with focus trap + focus restoration.
Implement dropdowns using a disclosure pattern by default (button + panel), unless the project has an established menu pattern.
Be SSR/hydration safe (no DOM access before mount).
Respect prefers-reduced-motion: reduce durations to <= tokens.motion.reducedMotionDurationMs and avoid transform-based animations where possible.
mustNot: Do not introduce a new styling system.
Do not use inline style attributes when vanilla CSS is detected.
Do not use role="menu" / role="menuitem" unless fully implementing the ARIA menu button pattern (arrow-key semantics, roles, and expectations).
Do not hardcode colors if the project uses design tokens or theme variables.

aiAgentInstructions.summary: Implement a responsive navigation bar with a mobile hamburger menu (modal dialog), sticky positioning (optional), optional transparent-to-solid scroll transition, and dropdown navigation. Dropdowns must work on desktop and integrate cleanly into the mobile dialog as accordion sections. Ensure WCAG AA compliance with correct ARIA, keyboard support, focus management, and reduced-motion behavior.
keyFeatures: Responsive: Desktop shows horizontal nav links; mobile/tablet show hamburger menu dialog
Sticky positioning: Fixed at top when scrolling (sticky=true)
Transparent→Solid: Background transitions on scroll (transparent=true; marketing recommended only)
Mobile menu: Modal dialog overlay with focus trap, focus restoration, inert/aria-hidden background, and body scroll lock
Dropdowns: Desktop disclosure dropdown panels; Mobile integrates dropdowns as accordion sections inside the dialog
Accessibility: ARIA attributes, keyboard navigation, Escape handling, focus visibility
Active link: Highlights current route with aria-current="page"
Variants: Marketing (logo + links + CTA) and App (user menu, notifications)
CRITICAL: Styling MUST match the project's existing conventions. Detect framework and styling system first, then use ONLY that system.
CRITICAL: When detecting vanilla CSS, ALWAYS create CSS classes in a stylesheet. NEVER use inline style attributes on HTML elements.
implementationSteps: 0. CRITICAL: Detect framework + router + styling system + design tokens using projectDetection before writing code.
1. Build component anatomy: Logo, NavLinks (desktop), MobileToggle, Actions (CTA/User Menu/Notifications), DropdownPanels, MobileMenu (dialog).
2. Implement controlled/uncontrolled state for mobileMenuOpen and openDropdownId (desktop).
3. Mobile dropdown integration: render items with children as accordion sections inside the mobile dialog (expand/collapse without closing the dialog).
4. Add scroll detection for sticky and transparent→solid behavior (requestAnimationFrame or ~100ms throttle).
5. Mobile dialog a11y: focus trap, initial focus, focus restoration to toggle, Escape close, backdrop click close, inert/aria-hidden background.
6. Body scroll lock when mobile dialog is open; cleanup on close/unmount; add iOS handling if needed.
7. Desktop dropdown behavior: click toggle opens/closes; outside click closes; Escape closes and restores focus to the toggle; optionally close on route change.
8. Apply ARIA: navigation landmark, dialog semantics for mobile, disclosure semantics for dropdowns, aria-current for active route.
9. Add animations + prefers-reduced-motion behavior (avoid transform-based motion if reduced).
10. Implement active link detection via the project's routing solution.
11. Use ONLY the detected styling system and match naming/import conventions exactly.
12. Provide a test checklist covering keyboard + screen reader flows for mobile dialog and dropdowns.

componentSpec.goal: Provide a responsive navigation bar that adapts to screen sizes, supports sticky/transparent behavior, and includes accessible mobile menu and dropdown navigation.

anatomy.hierarchy: Navbar → Logo | NavLinks (desktop, includes dropdown toggles/panels) | MobileToggle | Actions → MobileMenu (dialog) → NavLinks (accordion) | Actions

mobileMenuOpen.description: Whether the mobile menu dialog is visible.

scrolled.description: Whether the page has scrolled beyond the threshold (used for transparent→solid and sticky elevation).

activeLink.determination: Compare current URL/route with navigation link hrefs

variant.description: Navbar style variant: marketing (logo + links + CTA) or app (user menu, notifications).

sticky.description: Whether the navbar is sticky (fixed to top).
sticky.notes: Default true for both variants. Set sticky=false explicitly if needed.

transparent.description: Whether the navbar starts transparent and becomes solid on scroll.
transparent.notes: Recommended only for marketing variant and only when contrast is sufficient (e.g., hero behind). If variant=app, force transparent=false.

openDropdownId.description: ID of the currently open desktop dropdown (null/empty means none).
openDropdownId.notes: Desktop only. Prefer a single open dropdown at a time for predictability.

mobileExpandedItemIds.description: IDs of expanded accordion sections inside the mobile dialog for items that have children.
mobileExpandedItemIds.notes: Mobile dialog only. Allow multiple expanded sections unless the product requires single-open behavior.

interactions.accessibilityNotes: Escape closes the mobile dialog and restores focus to the toggle button.
Toggling an accordion section must not close the mobile dialog; focus remains within the dialog.
Outside click closes the open dropdown panel.
Escape closes dropdown and returns focus to its toggle.
Close the mobile dialog when switching to desktop breakpoint (>=1024px).

mobile.behavior: Logo left, hamburger right. Desktop links hidden. Mobile menu opens as modal dialog. Items with children render as accordion sections. Actions shown in the dialog.
mobile.mobileMenu: Modal dialog overlay; full-screen or slide-in panel.

tablet.behavior: Default to mobile dialog pattern. Dropdown items still behave as accordion sections inside the dialog.

desktop.behavior: Logo left, nav links horizontal, actions right. Items with children open disclosure dropdown panels on click (no hover-only behavior). Mobile menu hidden.

variants.marketing: Logo + horizontal nav + primary CTA. Sticky by default. Optional transparent-on-hero mode (transparent=true) that becomes solid on scroll. Dropdowns supported for grouped marketing sections.
variants.app: Logo + nav + notifications + user menu. Solid background only (transparent forced false). Sticky by default. Dropdowns commonly used for user menu and nav groupings.

navItems.description: Navigation items for desktop and mobile. Supports hierarchical dropdowns (children).
navItems.notes: If items[] is present, treat the item as a dropdown/accordion parent. Parent may optionally also have an href (product-specific).

userMenu.description: App variant user menu trigger and items.

shape.label: string (optional)
shape.items: array of { id, label, href | onSelect }

stickyScroll.implementation: Use requestAnimationFrame or throttle (~100ms) for scroll detection

dropdownOpen.notes: If prefers-reduced-motion is enabled, avoid transform and reduce durations to <= tokens.motion.reducedMotionDurationMs.

dropdownClose.notes: If prefers-reduced-motion is enabled, avoid transform and reduce durations to <= tokens.motion.reducedMotionDurationMs.

requirements.2.1.1: All navbar controls operable via keyboard; focus trapped within mobile dialog while open.
requirements.2.1.2: Escape closes mobile dialog and dropdowns; no keyboard trap beyond intended modal focus trap.
requirements.2.4.3: Logical focus order; focus returns to the correct toggle when overlays close.
requirements.2.4.7: Visible focus indicators for all interactive elements.
requirements.4.1.2: Correct ARIA roles, names, and relationships.

keyboardNavigation.escapeKey: Closes mobile dialog when open; otherwise closes an open desktop dropdown; restores focus to the corresponding toggle.
keyboardNavigation.tabKey: Mobile dialog traps focus while open; desktop dropdown panels do not trap focus (use normal Tab order).
keyboardNavigation.initialFocus: On opening mobile dialog, move focus to the first focusable element inside the dialog (often first nav link).

mobileMenu.aria-hidden: true when closed; false/omitted when open
mobileMenu.note: Mobile menu uses dialog semantics because it is modal with focus trap. Inside the dialog, include <nav aria-label="Main navigation"> for links.

desktopDropdownToggle.note: Prefer disclosure semantics: button controls a panel of links. Avoid role="menu" unless fully implementing menu keyboard semantics.

desktopDropdownPanel.note: Panel is a container for links; do not assign role="menu" unless implementing full menu pattern.

logo.alt: Descriptive alt text for logo image

notes: Mobile dialog: implement focus trap and restore focus to the menu toggle on close.
Desktop dropdown: on Escape, close dropdown and restore focus to its toggle. Do not trap focus inside dropdown panels.
If multiple overlays exist (mobile dialog + dropdowns), the mobile dialog is the top-level focus scope; do not open desktop dropdowns behind it.

implementationChecklist: Mobile menu uses role="dialog" + aria-modal="true" and contains <nav aria-label="Main navigation">
Mobile menu toggle has id, aria-expanded, and aria-controls
Focus trap is active only while the mobile dialog is open; focus restores to the menu toggle on close
Background content is inert/aria-hidden while the mobile dialog is open
Body scroll lock is applied when mobile dialog is open and cleaned up on close
Desktop dropdown toggles have aria-expanded + aria-controls; Escape closes and restores focus
Mobile dropdowns are accordions with aria-expanded + aria-controls; expanding does not close the dialog
All interactive elements have visible focus indicators
Prefers-reduced-motion reduces durations and avoids transform motion where possible

react.stateManagement: useState for component state; custom hooks for scroll, focus trap, scroll lock, dropdown state, and outside click
react.customHooks: Keep one concern per hook: useScrollPosition(threshold), useBodyScrollLock(isLocked), useFocusTrap(ref, isActive), useOutsideClick(ref, handler, enabled), useReducedMotion().

vue.stateManagement: ref/reactive for state; composables for scroll/outside click; watch for route changes

angular.stateManagement: Component fields; RxJS streams for scroll/resize; host listeners for Escape/outside click

svelte.stateManagement: writable stores for shared state; onMount for scroll; actions for outside click and focus trap

testingChecklist: Navbar renders correctly on all breakpoints
Mobile menu dialog opens and closes via toggle, Escape, backdrop click, and link click
Focus is trapped within the mobile dialog while open
Focus is restored to the mobile toggle when the dialog closes
Body scroll is locked while the mobile dialog is open and restored on close
Sticky positioning works correctly when enabled
Transparent→Solid transition works on scroll when enabled (marketing only)
Active link is highlighted correctly and uses aria-current="page"
Desktop dropdown opens/closes on toggle click
Desktop dropdown closes on outside click and Escape
Escape on desktop dropdown restores focus to the dropdown toggle
Desktop dropdown does not trap focus; Tab order is logical
Mobile dropdown items render as accordions inside the dialog
Mobile accordion expand/collapse updates aria-expanded and does not close the dialog
Route changes update active link and close open overlays if required by product rules
Window resize closes the mobile dialog when switching to desktop breakpoint
Prefers-reduced-motion reduces durations and avoids transform motion where possible
All interactive elements have visible focus indicators
Screen reader announces dialog state changes and expanded/collapsed states appropriately
SSR/hydration safe (no DOM access before mount)
aiImplementationPrompt: Implement a responsive Navigation Bar component with mobile hamburger menu as a modal dialog (role="dialog" aria-modal="true") including focus trap, focus restoration, inert background, and body scroll lock. Support sticky scroll behavior and optional transparent-to-solid transition (marketing recommended only). Add dropdown navigation: on desktop, implement disclosure dropdowns (button controlling a panel of links with aria-expanded/aria-controls; avoid role="menu" unless fully implementing ARIA menu semantics). On mobile/tablet, integrate dropdown items as accordion sections inside the dialog (aria-expanded/aria-controls), and expanding must not close the dialog. Close the mobile dialog on Escape/backdrop/link click. Close desktop dropdown on outside click/Escape and restore focus to its toggle. Implement smooth animations and prefers-reduced-motion (reduce durations to <= tokens.motion.reducedMotionDurationMs and avoid transform-based motion where possible). Adapt to {{USER_FRAMEWORK}} and {{USER_STYLING_LIBRARY}}. CRITICAL: Use ONLY the detected styling system. If vanilla CSS is detected, create CSS classes in a stylesheet; never use inline style attributes. If React is detected, separate effects into single-concern hooks.
